Quantified Assessments
Bloom’s Training Framework provides a simple, dynamic, and adaptive learning environment for individuals, teams, and organizations through a guided approach to project-based and cohort-based learning. 
The Framework helps people and teams improve along 2 Core Pillars: 
1) The Individual: Universal Skills, Wellbeing and Engagement (PERMAH) and Character Strengths
2) The Organization: Organization Development
The Framework helps individuals and teams assess core areas of strengths and weaknesses, and then prioritize specific areas for further learning and development. 
The Bloom platform provides guidance and suggested activities for improvement across both pillars, with an emphasis on supporting development in both pillars simultaneously, such as working on improving a specific individual skill through activities that are helping with a core organizational need. 
The Bloom Training Framework can be used in different contexts: Inside companies or organizations, in project-based learning programs (youth, school, university, etc), in startup accelerators, for short events such as startup sprints or hackathons, or others. 
Pillar 1: The Individual  
Includes: Universal Skills (skills relevant to all roles, and in both personal and professional contexts, others may call them soft skills and they have a significant overlap with 21st Century Skills), Wellbeing & Engagement, and Character Strengths (most commonly used to help people identify their Signature Strengths to leverage in their work and personal growth areas).

Universal Skills (Universal Skills relevant for all aspects of work and life): 
Listening, Speaking, Problem Solving, Creativity, Staying Positive, Aiming High, Leadership, Teamwork
Wellbeing & Engagement at work and life (through PERMAH): 
Positive Emotion,  Engagement, Positive Relationships, Meaning, Accomplishments/Achievements, Vitality & Health
Character Strengths (through VIA, Values in Action) 
Wisdom and Knowledge: creativity, curiosity, judgment, love of learning, perspective
Courage: bravery, perseverance, honesty, zest
Humanity: love, kindness, social intelligence
Justice: teamwork, fairness, leadership
Temperance: forgiveness, humility, prudence, self-regulation
Transcendence: appreciation of beauty and excellence, gratitude, hope, humor, spirituality

Universal Skills 
help people regardless of their sector or role within an organization. These represent the training component of the personal development framework. The Universal Skills help our teams develop skills that will support them no matter their personal or professional requirements. 
We use the Universal Skills Framework from SkillsBuilder.org to help people build skills along four dimensions:
Communication: Listening, Speaking
Creative Problem Solving: Problem Solving, Creativity
Self-Management: Staying Positive, Aiming High
Collaboration: Leadership, Teamwork

Wellbeing and Engagement 
This assessment comes from the school of positive psychology and is a measure of human flourishing. 
Positivity, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, Achievement, and Health are all ends in themselves. 
Scoring highly on one or many of these factors is one way to determine a life well-lived. 
We use this measure to help focus our programs on the idea that the success of an organization can, and should, come hand in hand with personal success. 
Our Character Strengths 
Our Character Strengths can be great tools to guide us in developing skills and being effective at whatever we do. Leveraging them makes learning and doing new things easier and more fun.
In Bloom programs, we use the Values in Action Character Strengths assessment to help individuals identify their “Signature Strength”. It is a strength that shows up quickly and authentically, giving people energy when it’s used rather than taking effort. 
Using our Signature Strengths can unlock energy and promote wellbeing at work. 
The assessment represents an analysis of virtues and values held by people around the world. Twenty-four Character Strengths are unequivocally known to be good. We can cluster these Strengths into seven virtues.
How to apply the Individual Development Framework

Request your participants to take the Bloom Individual Development assessments on the Bloom Platform, which include Universal Skills, Wellbeing and Engagement, and Character Strengths.
After the individuals take the assessments, you can request individuals and teams to identify their Signature Strengths.
Once they’ve identified their Signature Strengths, request individuals to select a priority area within their Universal Skills results on the Bloom Learn tab.
In program cycles, discussions with peers, mentors, and program managers can help participants identify & improve individual growth priorities and select activities for development from their personal knowledge, online resources, or from the Bloom Library of Activities. 
End of the program assessments helps participants and program managers see growth and chart paths for further improvement.

Pillar 2: The Organization 

Includes: Organization Development system with specific assessments adapted to the needs of teams and programs. 

Strategy
Innovation & Learning
Advocacy
Impact Monitoring (M&E) or Corporate Social Responsibility
Programs and Projects or Products and Services
Community Engagement & Communication
Infrastructure
Team, Leadership, Staff & Volunteers
Revenues & Financial Sustainability
Financial Management
Legal & Compliance
Risk, Security & Resilience

Organization Capacity is the ability of an organization to achieve its mission while anticipating and managing future changes and risks. 
We’ve derived our organization capacity assessment from methodologies used by international consulting firms, and adapted it for enterprises and accelerators. 
Bloom’s Organization Capacities assessment helps organizations identify blind spots, giving them a 360-degree perspective on where they stand as an organization and helping them pick the areas of organization development which will help them most. We have adapted versions of the assessment for enterprises, early-stage enterprises, and accelerators.

How to apply the Organization Development Framework

The program manager invites teams and participants to take the relevant Organization Capacities assessment on the Bloom platform (Enterprise Capacities or Accelerator Capacities). 
After participants take the assessment, they are invited to go over their results and discuss with their team, mentor, and program manager to identify their priority areas of development and the particular objectives they would like to achieve during the program. 
The Organization Development Plan is documented using Bloom’s template for the duration of the program and shared between the teams, the mentors, and the program manager. 
Regular progress check-ins during program cycles help the team, mentors, and program managers stay on track, adjust where needed, solve problems, and track progress.
Teams periodically take the assessment (whole or just for their priority development areas) to celebrate growth and improvements!

More information can be found here: Bloom Framework v0.8 - Two Pillars (ready-approved)

Bloom Digital Library

We are putting forward a collection of reusable training materials and learning resources developed by experts to help young people develop their enterprises and personal and professional skills.
The Library of Activities is an element of the Bloom Platform where young people can take assessments, evaluate their enterprises and skills, and find specialized training resources with actionable worksheets.
Example score results:
Program manager views showcasing a summary of youth activity onthe platform: 

Youth can identify their growth areas by selecting the category that’s a priority for them and by adding a growth goal as a description. This provides program managers and coaches a dashboard where they can see overall team needs, matchmake teams based on who has strengths to offer and who may need them, as well as offer suggested activities directly from library to the participants taskboards.



Using tasks to monitor activities is one way to support learning by doing. After taking an assessment we program managers have the ability to track the progress of the activities on a single dashboard for all the participants and are able to encourage those who haven’t yet done the activity by sending messages. 


Bloom Digital Library:
The Bloom Library aims to provide the coaches and teams of our programs with free access to learning content to support their growth. The library is matched to our assessment framework, so each area a team and coach identify as a potential area for development has the resources at hand to support them. We have curated training modules from local and international expert trainers, which include video lessons and immediately applicable worksheets on all categories of our 360-degree enterprise assessment (ECAT). Our library also includes free access to digital books, audiobooks, and worksheets.
Library members can borrow e-books and audiobooks on different subjects, including entrepreneurship, organizational development, skills development, social entrepreneurship, and wellbeing. 
https://www.bloom.pm/library/ 



We hope the coaches benefit from our SOPs and digital services to provide high-quality tailored coaching to teams remotely and in person. 

Customizing the Curriculum
We strive to adapt the curriculum to each new cohort of enterprises that best caters to their needs. We base this customization on inputs from
The assessment results of each enterprise: We look at the score trends in each category.
The Team's Organization Development Plans: We look at each objective and critical result and extract the categories related to the activities planned.
A survey of the most common categories of training topics: We ask the entrepreneurs to tell us what topics they are most interested in learning.

Learning by Doing
When it comes to entrepreneurship, there is nothing more important than the act of “doing” and “testing” to understand the product, customers, and business model. At Bloom, we know how much theory we introduce to entrepreneurs versus how much time we give them to achieve results. Teaching entrepreneurs theory is inevitable — it is crucial to understand the context — but we make sure that every idea comes with a framework or a tool that entrepreneurs can use and develop over time to achieve their goals. These tools make robust theories actionable. Once we introduce them to our program, we make an effort to revisit them during the program over and over again, in the best spirit of lean startup methodology, so we make sure we are helping the startups drive progress and results.

Modular Learning
Modular learning, as the word connotes, uses learning modules that facilitate entrepreneurs learning by themselves. Thus, modular learning is a form of distance learning that uses Self-Learning Modules based on the essential learning competencies developed by our team of trainers with the aid of curriculum developers.
When there’s teaching, it’s tempting to sit students down in a classroom and show them what they need to know. But Village Capital claims that “the more remote work we allow, the better.” For example, indirect learning, which focuses on the student’s inquiry and exploration rather than the teacher’s instruction, allows entrepreneurs to learn while working on their business plans and product. 
Accelerators should design curricula around things entrepreneurs do remotely that serve the dual function of teaching valuable lessons and helping advance the startup. It is better to use the time to build relationships and get feedback. Online education with e-learning modules allows founders to spend more time building networks and products.

KEY POINTS: 
Curriculums are customized according to teams’ Enterprise Capacities results, Organization Development Plan, surveys, and one-on-one interviews to identify the most present needs
Content is created well before training sessions so entrepreneurs can learn at their own pace, apply their learning on homework, templates, and tools, and get feedback in sessions with the trainers.
DIAGNOSTIC & TOOLKIT: (assessments, checklists, models, templates) 
Program Planning Template v2
Bloom Digital Library

Facilitation Tools 
The dashboard area on the Bloom platform will allow coaches to see the priority category the teams have chosen to develop, the assigned activities they selected together, and a summary of their work plan.
We also provide our coaches with a Program Dashboard template which helps them set Objectives and Key Results(OKRs) with their teams and provides a dashboard for them to use during their coaching sessions. 
We include the OKR work plan template below for review. 






Enterprise Stage Focus

Bloom has experience working with enterprises and impact initiatives at different stages of development. We use the staged assessment to help coaches identify where a team is at and what might be their next steps towards their next stage. We also use stage assessments for program impact purposes as one of the measures of team growth. 

Stages
Sub-Stages
0. LEARNING	
0.1. Learning without the goal of launching an enterprise
1. IDEATION
1.1. Want to start and look for/testing ideas
2. IDEA-STAGE
2.1. Exploring ideas, conducting market/customer research 
2.2. Have started developing my idea
3. PROTOTYPE
3.1. Have an early (low-fidelity/paper) prototype (of product or service)
3.2.  Have a functioning (high-fidelity) prototype with early users / early adopters
4. EARLY-STAGE
4.1. Declining revenues and the enterprise is not yet profitable/sustainable
4.2. Revenues are stagnant or growing slowly, but the enterprise is not however profitable/sustainable
4.3. Revenues are growing quickly, but the enterprise is not yet profitable/sustainable
5. GROWTH-STAGE
5.1. Profitable/sustainable business (with stable, growing, or declining revenues)
5.2. Seeking scalability (of impact and/or profits)
5.3. Seeking diversification 
5.4. Seeking an exit 
5.5. Established national enterprise
5.6. Established multinational enterprise

Program Stages
The Sprint
Our Sprint, by definition, is a short program that helps young people take a giant leap into thinking about their potential. Lasting anywhere between 3-10 days, though they can be as short as one fun and intense day. 
It’s loosely adapted what’s known as “The Design Sprint, “ a combination of Design Thinking, Lean Startup, and Agile approach, based on a series of steps and techniques that help young people solve their product! In a nutshell, it’s a way for young people to spend a fixed amount of time on core venture development using today’s best practices in a coherent, integrated fashion. 

In Bloom’s standard programs, the sprint has two main objectives: 
To help young people learn new skills and progress in their projects. 
To help us learn more about them during our selection process for the Accelerator. 

We’ve found that we learn more about the people and projects through a short Sprint program than through an application process and interviews. We’ve also found that intense short Sprints are a very efficient approach to increase contact hours and increase the possibility of new relationships.


The Accelerator

Below are the five principles that guide the design of our accelerator programs.
Praxis: learning happens by doing and reflecting.
Praxis is the process by which a skill is embodied or realized. "Praxis" refers to engaging, applying, exercising, learning, or practicing ideas. Praxis is critical thinking that combines reflection and action.
Bloom tools: In our programs, this is applied by encouraging enterprises to record their daily tasks and activities on the Bloom task board. 
Strengths Oriented: use momentum and do more of what’s working.
The strength-based approach focuses on the positive attributes of a person or a group rather than the negative ones. This approach builds the entrepreneur on their strengths, specifically seeing them as resourceful and resilient when in adverse conditions. Strengths are integral to our human identity, constituting the intrinsic and inherent qualities that define us as individuals. However, few are conscious and appreciative of them or particular about how we can best put them to use to achieve desired outcomes.
Using strengths energizes and motivates individuals to contribute discretionary effort towards attaining their goals. At the same time, it nourishes a feeling of achievement because they perform the things they are best at doing. Research indicates that when individuals use their strengths, they feel happier, more confident and proud of themselves, and more engaged at work. In addition, they perform better while experiencing a sense of resilience in achieving their goals. 
Bloom tools: In our programs, we apply this by administering personal assessments to identify entrepreneurs’ strengths and capitalize on them through our library of activities that help build the strengths. Additionally, we developed the Enterprise Capacity Assessment to measure the organizational capacity of enterprises. It allows us to have the whole picture of the strengths of both the entrepreneur and the enterprise.
Growth Mindset: 1% better every day, 200% better in 70 days.
A growth mindset thrives on challenge and sees failure not as evidence of unintelligence but as a heartening springboard for growth and stretching our existing abilities. Individuals who believe their talents can be developed (through hard work, good strategies, and input from others) have a growth mindset. As a result, they tend to achieve more than those with a more fixed mindset (those who believe their talents are innate gifts). It is because they worry less about looking bright and put more energy into learning. 
Striving to get 1% better daily is a core tenet of the growth mindset principle. This system encourages action by breaking down big, overwhelming goals into small, discrete pieces. The small successes you experience with your baby steps feed on each other and start building momentum, leading to more prominent and significant moves.
We encourage our entrepreneurs to try to do just 1% better than the day before. Start small and make your increases gradual. Avoid the temptation to get impatient and start rushing forward and taking more significant leaps. Take it slow, steady, and consistent.
Simply try to do a little better than you did the day before. Daily, just focus on getting 1% better in whatever you try to improve. That’s it. Just 1%. It might not seem like much, but those 1% improvements compound each other. 
Bloom Tools: Our programs encourage entrepreneurs to look at their weekly power moves. Power Moves are the moves that take us out of our comfort zone and push us forward. Those exhilarating first steps allow us to make many more steps. Power Moves take you right out of your regularly scheduled program. They are the key to real change. They’re the most critical task that will take you one step closer to your goal.
Step by Step: Pick a target, make it tractable, get to it, and review it.
Breaking projects down into their parts is oft-repeated advice when tackling something big. Breaking tasks down helps us see large tasks as more approachable and doable and reduces our propensity to procrastinate or defer tasks because we simply don’t know where to begin.
Entrepreneurs should break down the tasks to a point where they can produce a reliable estimate. Each key objective should have a clearly defined task or set of tasks. Tasks should be between 8 and 80 person-hours of labor. It is a manageable amount.
Bloom Tools: We ask our teams to prepare an Organization Development Plan that includes at least one and up to three critical objectives tied into key results and broken down into significant activities or tasks. It allows us to understand what the enterprise intends to accomplish during the accelerator period. Additionally, we encourage enterprises to use the Bloom Taskboard to record their daily tasks and keep track of their progress to accomplish what they’ve planned within their set deadlines. 
Community: We grow best when we grow together.
We rarely grow alone. Being part of an engaging community gives us a sense of belonging. It enables us to share personal relatedness and support the perpetual growth of each other, ourselves, and our environment. Being a part of a community can make us feel like we are a part of something greater than ourselves. Providing unique opportunities for people to learn from each other and support and encouragement are invaluable in joining forces with our peers.
Bloom Tools: We aim to create a healthy community for our enterprises, starting with them:
The teams: Being part of a community enables us to support other members. Supporting others will help them feel good and better about themselves. 
The mentors: An open bond with new connections builds valuable relationships and gives us a more profound sense of belonging. It helps us to reach our goals and brings a sense of security.
The module leaders: Communities are rich in resources. Knowing is a unique resource, and through its use, it increases in value. 
We encourage entrepreneurs to use the inverted pyramid in the context of learning and feedback. First, they evaluate themselves, then get feedback from their mentors, and then the module leaders give feedback. 
The general architecture of a cycle
Bloom cycles takes the best from agile and design thinking methodologies used at leading innovation companies globally. We use these in our sprint and accelerator programs to help teams develop their startup while learning leading productivity techniques.

Conclusion
This provides an overview of our Curriculum and pedagogy. We have further documentation for training Program Managers on managing their programs which goes into further detail. We aim to continuously improve our methodology with each program we run and are open to feedback, feel free to email bilal@bloom.pm, habib@bloom.pm and dara@bloom.pm with your recommendations!

To align Bloom's educational principles with the existing SCRIBER and INSPIRE frameworks, we'll carefully consider each component and its relevance to the frameworks, along with assessments or tools where applicable. Let's incorporate the key elements of the Bloom Curriculum and Remote Accelerator Methodology, focusing on their core principles, facilitation tools, and the stages of the program.

### Bloom's Taxonomy Alignment

#### Pillar 1: The Individual
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Reflect, Seek, Inquire / Inquiry-Based Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Self-Assessment tools for Universal Skills, Wellbeing & Engagement, and Character Strengths

#### Pillar 2: The Organization
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Critique, Explain / Problem-Based Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Organization Development Self-Assessment Tool

#### Bloom Digital Library
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Broaden/Contract / Interactive & Collaborative Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Library Utilization Metrics & User Feedback

#### Facilitation Tools
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Recurse (as Metacognition), Reflect / Resilience & Grit, Narrative & Reflective Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Program Dashboard & Feedback Mechanisms

#### Program Stages: The Sprint & The Accelerator
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: All SCRIBER Elements / All INSPIRE Framework Elements
- **Assessment/Tool**: Stage-Specific Assessment Tools & Feedback Surveys

### Principles Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE

#### Youth in the Driver’s Seat
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Seek, Recurse / Self-Directed Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Decision-Making Skills Assessment

#### Transformation vs. Information
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Explain, Critique / Experiential Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Actionable Knowledge Application Assessment

#### Personal and Professional Assessments
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Inquire, Reflect / Inquiry-Based Learning, Narrative & Reflective Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Holistic Growth Assessment Tools

#### Community Aspect
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Broaden/Contract / Interactive & Collaborative Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Community Engagement Metrics

### Additional Components

#### Customizing the Curriculum
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Critique, Explain / Problem-Based Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Customization Effectiveness Feedback

#### Learning by Doing & Modular Learning
- **Alignment with SCRIBER/INSPIRE**: Seek, Recurse / Inquiry-Based Learning, Experiential Learning
- **Assessment/Tool**: Project Completion and Impact Analysis

By integrating Bloom's educational principles with the SCRIBER and INSPIRE frameworks, we align the curriculum with contemporary educational theories while ensuring a comprehensive approach to learning and development. This alignment also allows for the use of targeted assessments and tools to measure the effectiveness of each element within the Bloom curriculum.

For the INSPIRE prompt frame work describe it in great detail and then give some step by step examples of how it's used for each element

The INSPIRE framework represents a comprehensive approach to learning, encompassing various educational paradigms. Each element of INSPIRE corresponds to specific learning strategies and methodologies. Here's a detailed description of each element with step-by-step examples:

1. **Inquiry-Based Learning**
   - **Description:** This approach focuses on stimulating learners' curiosity and encouraging them to ask questions, investigate, and explore topics in-depth.
   - **Step-by-Step Example:** In a class on environmental science, students might be asked to choose a local environmental issue. They formulate questions, conduct research, and present their findings, thus actively engaging in the learning process.

2. **Narrative & Reflective Learning**
   - **Description:** This method uses storytelling and personal reflection to deepen understanding and create connections between the learner’s experiences and the subject matter.
   - **Step-by-Step Example:** Students in a literature class write a personal narrative relating a piece of literature to their own experiences, followed by reflecting on how this connection enhances their understanding of the text.

3. **Self-Directed Learning**
   - **Description:** Learners take the initiative in setting their own learning goals, choosing the resources, and evaluating their progress.
   - **Step-by-Step Example:** In a project on renewable energy, a student chooses to focus on solar power. They gather resources, plan their study, and periodically self-assess their understanding and progress.

4. **Problem-Based Learning**
   - **Description:** Learning occurs through solving real-world problems, encouraging application of knowledge in practical scenarios.
   - **Step-by-Step Example:** Medical students are presented with a patient case study. They must diagnose the patient, propose treatment options, and discuss potential outcomes, applying their medical knowledge.

5. **Interactive & Collaborative Learning**
   - **Description:** This focuses on learning through interaction and teamwork, where learners work together and learn from each other.
   - **Step-by-Step Example:** In a business class, students are divided into groups to develop a business plan. They collaborate, delegate tasks, and collectively solve problems, learning from each other’s skills and perspectives.

6. **Resilience & Grit**
   - **Description:** Developing persistence and resilience, focusing on overcoming challenges and learning from failures.
   - **Step-by-Step Example:** Students participate in a challenging coding marathon, where they encounter and have to overcome multiple programming obstacles, thereby learning persistence and problem-solving resilience.

7. **Experiential Learning**
   - **Description:** Learning through direct experience, hands-on activities, and reflection, linking theory to real-world application.
   - **Step-by-Step Example:** Students in a culinary course prepare dishes using various techniques. They reflect on the process and results, linking cooking methods to the scientific principles behind them.

8. **Self-Efficacy / Entrepreneurial Self-Efficacy**
   - **Description:** Developing confidence in one's ability to successfully navigate and complete specific tasks or challenges.
   - **Step-by-Step Example:** Entrepreneurship students are tasked with creating and running a small business for a term. Successes and challenges in this real-world application build their confidence in entrepreneurial abilities.

By employing the INSPIRE framework, educational programs can ensure a holistic and effective learning experience that addresses various aspects of learning and development, preparing learners for real-world challenges and fostering a lifelong love of learning.

Set Sail on an Adventure with Your Navigator's Talking Map!

S.C.R.I.B.E.R For Adults
Prompt Techniques to Help You Think Yourself
Introduction
Artificial intelligence is changing the world of work. Some people are getting great results, and some find LLMs, like chatGPT, fun yet useless for “the real world of work.” The opportunity is there, yet it requires us to learn how LLMs work, and from there, we will be able to get better results.
In a nutshell, LLMs store knowledge in a graph representing ideas in space. By speaking to it, you move around in this graph. Once you’re somewhere in the graph, you can ask it what is around you that you “can’t see.” 
This framework will allow you to use chatGPT and other LLMs to help you think, not think for you. We developed these principles to help you experience this intuition about how LLMs operate and to teach you that you can now, perhaps for the first time in history, teach yourself the things you don’t even know you don’t know.
May you wield this tool well and create great benefits for yourself, your communities, and the world.
The S.C.R.I.B.E.R Framework for Prompting
Seek: Exploring your gaps in different domains of knowledge.
Critique: Actively seek constructive critique from antagonist personas.
Reflect: Procedurally review the LLM’s work and create tools to think with.
Inquire: Ask the AI to ask you questions to help it navigate to new spaces.
Broaden/Contract: Seek gaps. Ask the LLM for non-overlapping options and pick.
Explain: Ask LLM to share its reasoning for transparency and corrections.
Recurse: Ask the LLM to ask it to ask you to ask it.

The following table shares the SCRIBE Framework in three parts.
Principles are ideas that you keep it in mind and attempt to act upon them.
Techniques are how you can apply the principles. It’s just one method of many.
The Way of Being is a quality of presence from which the principles and techniques can emerge. It can be cultivated by repeated practice of the techniques and deep reflection on the principles. It is what matters in the end.

Note: Do NOT memorize this list. 
These techniques and principles are tools to help us embody the knowledge. Aim to have a mindset of using LLMs as a tool for thought. 
Experts don't recite steps; they embody their knowledge. Imagine a chef constantly looking up recipes! It's not about following a checklist; it's about making the knowledge a part of who you are. It’s from here that new principles and techniques will emerge. 
The ultimate goal of learning is to become.

Certainly! Let's create a table for the INSPIRE framework, which serves as a guiding approach for prompt-based learning, much like the S.C.R.I.B.E.R framework. The INSPIRE framework can be broken down into various elements, each with a unique focus on enhancing learning and thought processes. This table will outline each element of the INSPIRE framework, describe its focus, and suggest techniques and principles aligned with it, similar to the structure of the S.C.R.I.B.E.R framework.

| INSPIRE Element | Description | Way of Being ❤️ | Technique 🤲 | Principle 🧠 |
|-----------------|-------------|-----------------|--------------|-------------|
| **I**nnovate | Encourage creative thinking and novel solutions. | Open to New Ideas | Brainstorming sessions; Idea mapping. | Fostering creativity and innovation in problem-solving. |
| **N**avigate | Guide through complex information or tasks. | Purposeful and Directed | Setting clear goals; Step-by-step guidance. | Assisting in finding the path through complex or new areas of knowledge. |
| **S**ynthesize | Combine different ideas and concepts to form a cohesive understanding. | Integrative | Merging concepts from different sources; Creating summaries. | Blending diverse thoughts or concepts into a unified whole. |
| **P**robe | Delve deeper into subjects to uncover underlying principles. | Inquisitive | Asking deeper, targeted questions; Seeking underlying causes. | Exploring beneath the surface to gain deeper understanding. |
| **I**nterpret | Understand and explain the meaning of information or data. | Analytical | Analyzing data or text; Translating complex ideas into understandable concepts. | Deciphering and making sense of information. |
| **R**eflect | Consider and evaluate one’s own learning and understanding. | Self-Aware | Journaling; Self-assessment. | Engaging in self-evaluation and contemplation about the learning process. |
| **E**ngage | Actively involve in the learning process and discussions. | Engaged and Participatory | Group discussions; Interactive activities. | Taking an active role in learning and contributing to discussions or activities. |

Each element of the INSPIRE framework serves a distinct purpose in the learning process, facilitating a comprehensive and multifaceted approach to education. The techniques and principles listed provide a starting point for implementing each aspect of INSPIRE in a learning environment, similar to how S.C.R.I.B.E.R functions in prompting and guiding learning through interaction with AI.

To create the INSPIRE framework with examples of prompting approaches that embody each element, I'll use the style and techniques from the S.C.R.I.B.E.R framework. This will include examples of how these principles can be applied to foster exploration, understanding, and growth in various learning scenarios.

| INSPIRE Element | Description | SCRIBER Alignment | Prompt Example |
|-----------------|-------------|-------------------|----------------|
| **I**nnovate | Encourage creative thinking and novel solutions. | Seek, Broaden/Contract | "Imagine a world where conventional rules don't apply. What innovative solution might work here that wouldn’t work elsewhere?" |
| **N**avigate | Guide through complex information or tasks. | Inquire | "If you were leading an exploration through this unknown topic, what key landmarks would you look for?" |
| **S**ynthesize | Combine different ideas and concepts to form a cohesive understanding. | Reflect, Explain | "How could you blend these two theories to form a new understanding? What would that synthesis look like?" |
| **P**robe | Delve deeper into subjects to uncover underlying principles. | Critique | "Dive deep into this concept. What are its foundations, and how do they challenge what we currently believe?" |
| **I**nterpret | Understand and explain the meaning of information or data. | Explain | "Can you act as a translator for this complex idea, explaining it in simple terms to someone unfamiliar with the topic?" |
| **R**eflect | Consider and evaluate one’s own learning and understanding. | Reflect | "After learning this, how has your perspective changed? What insights have you gained?" |
| **E**ngage | Actively involve in the learning process and discussions. | Seek, Inquire | "How can you contribute your unique understanding to this discussion, enhancing our collective exploration of the topic?" |

Each of these prompt examples is designed to invoke a specific aspect of the INSPIRE framework, encouraging deeper engagement, critical thinking, and active participation in the learning process. The alignment with SCRIBER techniques ensures that the prompts are practical, actionable, and supportive of a wide range of learning styles and objectives.

Yeah, so the idea of getting stuck in a cultural relative minimum is a real problem. Thank you for asking. I think it's really important to see this as an opportunity rather than as a challenge. The large language models have been trained on mostly Western data languages that have been present and available online for a long time. And it's not because of any bias, it's just how the Internet develops, where the resources for it utilize it, and how it grew over time. And even the Internet is developing its own culture. And so I think it's possible and interesting to add an element where we can have people suggest alongside curiosity and risk, or even maybe as a subcategory inside of risk, in the risk assessment prompt.

It sounds like you're aware of the cultural limitations of large language models (LLMs) and want to mitigate this in your project. Your idea of incorporating a feature where users can suggest content related to cultural relevance as part of the risk assessment is intriguing. This could help in diversifying the perspectives and data that the AI works with. 

Here are a few suggestions to enhance your approach:

1. **Cultural Sensitivity Filters:** Implement filters in your AI model that identify and address culturally specific nuances. This might include adapting the language or examples the AI uses based on the user's cultural background.

2. **User Feedback Mechanism:** Create a system where users can provide feedback on AI responses. This data can be used to continuously improve the cultural relevance and sensitivity of the AI.

3. **Diverse Data Sources:** To combat the Western-centric nature of most LLMs, actively seek out and incorporate datasets from diverse linguistic and cultural backgrounds.

4. **Ethical Advisory Board:** Consider establishing an advisory board with experts in cultural studies, ethics, and AI to guide the development and implementation of culturally sensitive AI models.

5. **Localized Testing and Adaptation:** Conduct pilot tests in various cultural settings to understand how well the AI performs and make necessary adaptations.

Remember, while technology like LLMs can be powerful, they also reflect the data they are trained on. Actively working to make your AI more culturally sensitive is a significant step towards creating a more inclusive and effective tool.
